comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
At the junction of Sussex and Market Streets, looking east.  The Governor Bourke Hotel is on the NE Corner.  The men are walking towards the old Pyrmont Bridge behind.

Same crossroads in 1900 - 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4349494121/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Governor Bourke Hotel seems to have been the subject of nostalgic art - Livingstone Hopkins - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=66350&PICTAUS=TRUE Lionel Lindsay - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=92690&PICTAUS=TRUE Julian Ashton - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=189324# I wonder why?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Compare with this 1896 view from virtually the same vantage point. Spot the differences! - [View from Hotel Jubilee, right, looking towards Queen Victoria Market dome at the time of its opening] (1896) by A. J. Perier [SLNSW: perier_34467]

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Lol. You pipped me at the post. I was just in middle of typing this long rant and was having trouble posting this image when pellethepoet posted the above :p To add to this: I can't make out the name of the one in the background. Perhaps it wasn't a hotel for long as none of the other images show this as a pub - in fact in the one above it's a bank. What this photo doesn't reveal is that the hotel on the SE corner behind the men walking (and clearly seen above) was called the Boomerang and was there since about 1869. Today its the site of the Shelbourne Hotel, built in 1902 - the same year as the new Pyrmont Bridge, which ran onto Market street, was built. This photo shows that the Jubilee & the Governor Bourke were demolished when the new bridge was built. These images all capture so well the dramatic changes on this site that happened in only a few short years. Here endeth the history rant ...

comment._content: Hey SLNSW are you able to see what it says on the side of that building? We think it's a hotel, but none of us can read it :-)

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I've tried to 'enhance' the writing in Photoshop. I'm 99% certain it's "HOTEL".  Above that appears to be a word with seven letters possibly starting "WA...".  It almost looks like "WANNABE"!

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: By squinting at the high resolution image, I think it says Mahony's Hotel. According to Trove, there was a Mahony's Hotel at 1 Market St in the 1880s. It comes up in the SMH advertising sections every now and then.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Thanks now it's all clear! James Mahony was the publican of the Old Boomerang Hotel. This hotel was actually the old colonial building next to the taller white building on which Mahony's Hotel was written. He must have got permission to advertise on the side of the taller building, where it would be seen from a decent distance. trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/result?q=%22boomerang+hotel%22...

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Forget my efforts with Photoshop then, which were way off - once again the good old analogue technique of squinting solves a mystery!

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Lol! I couldn't do it by squinting either!
